description: From Middle English confessioun, from Old French confession, from Latin cōnfessiō, cōnfessiōnem (“confession, acknowledgment, creed or avowal of one's faith”). Displaced native Old English andetnes. Doublet of confessio.

entries.meaning: The open admittance of having done something (especially something bad).
examples: Without the real murderer's confession, an innocent person will go to jail.

entries.meaning: A formal document providing such an admission.
examples: He forced me to sign a confession!

entries.meaning: (Christianity) The disclosure of one's sins to a priest for absolution. In the Roman Catholic Church, it is now also termed the sacrament of reconciliation.
examples: I went to confession and now I feel much better about what I had done.

entries.meaning: Acknowledgment of belief; profession of one's faith.
A formula in which the articles of faith are comprised; a creed to be assented to or signed, as a preliminary to admission to membership of a church; a confession of faith.
